comments.commentBody:
The BAIZE-BANS-NRA bit was a complete Natick for me. I've never heard of BAIZE, and BANS being a school edicts seems like an arbitrary clue pulled out of a hat.

As for NO-LOOK PASS, I had NO GOOD PASS*; I suppose I should have wondered about "A GAS* the day", but it didn't register as odd, and MADE IT* instead of MAKE IT slipped through when I missed the tense.

I agree with the commenter who cited "de jure" as a bad clue. Too many of the non-theme clues missed the mark for my taste. I gave up at the Natick section, which I haven't done with a Times puzzle in an extremely long time.
I had the exact same problems!! Happy to feel that I wasn't alone in my confusion.
Craig, you clearly never read enough gothic novels!  The big spooky house always had a green baize door that was the entrance to the basement servants' quarters and kitchen area.

Not just gothic, Liz. Murder mysteries by the dozens, if they're set in stately homes.

But I've never understood why the door was covered with the same stuff that's used on pool tables.

I am a big fan of Joe Biden, and even I admit that he screwed up the Thomas confirmation hearings very badly. Anita Hill spoke truth to power and deserved far better than she received in the Clarence Thomas hearings.

As for Clarence Thomas, he was a poor choice for the Supreme Court and has contributed little to the Court's jurisprudence. Whatever his personal conduct toward Hill-- which appears dubious-- he has served neither the public nor the Court well.
Joe Biden: plagiarist, enabler, defender of the interests of usurious Delaware corporations.
Despite his silence, his impact has been negative in that he could be relied upon to double Scalia's right wing vote and SCOTUS is stuck with him until he decides to resign or dies.

Justice Thomas is just a "bench warmer" in the worst sense of the term.  We are paying an exorbitant salary to one who just performs at a minimalist level, and yet will collect salary, benefits and pension forever.  There used to be a lot of these low-value, non performers in Corporate America, but executive greed and tough economic times have wrung many of them out of jobs.    This is a good year to "flush" dysfunctional members of Congress out of office for non-performance, especially the Senate that will not even agree to meet with President OBama's nominee.  They are supposed to work for us citizens, but in the words of their forthcoming Presidential nominee, we should just say to them, "You're FIRED" !

The truly scary and offensive demonstration of Trump's popularity is the many seemingly adult Americans who are lapping this up, and are backing him to the hilt (at least so far).

His sexist, racist, bullying, xenophobic, fear-driven, fascist "Let's Make America White Again" dark cartoon of a presidential campaign has opened the closet doors for the millions who have thought or felt like this, but now have a legitimatized outlet for their feelings.

We will have to deal with the real consequences of their having gotten permission and blessings to speak and act out those feelings for years to come.

Why are there 15 types of Cheerios? Cereal manufacturers count on public gullibility. Fruity Cheerios are Froot Loops. Apple Cinnamon Cheerios are nutritionally void Apple Jacks. But shoppers trust the Cheerios label and their children recognize the symbols, even if they can't yet read. You pay $5 for about 30 cents worth of grain. But it's easy to serve, no prep required.

It's called "ribbonizing".  Tradition suggests that as a food company you want as many SKU's (basically shelf positions by product) as possible.  Basically, you want your own "wall of brands" so you can own your category aisle...or as much as possible. To achieve this you make brand extensions to support your positions the retailers plan-o-gram (blueprint for products on shelf).  Although, recently, in some categories it has been proven that some makers give the consumers too many choices and thus confuse them.
Be careful what you wish for.  I remember Democrats celebrating in 1968 when Nixon won the Republican nomination.
He is not "isolating" the other child; he just does not want to be friends with him.

South Carolina was one of only six states to vote for Barry Goldwater in 1964 and has voted Republican since, except in 1976 when it voted for fellow southerner Jimmy Carter.

In 2012, Mitt Romney defeated Barack Obama 55% to 44% in South Carolina.

While Ms. Clinton deserves credit for winning the South Carolina primary, she will not be winning this state in November 2016, and she will fare similarly in the rest of Red Republistan.

Her November 2016 electability remains a very cloudy picture.
But she was a Goldwater girl.
thanks for reminder about goldwater who voted against the civil rights act.
She was 15 at the time.  Her parents were conservative.  She became a Democrat in college.  Liz Warren was a Republican much longer than that.

8 years after the financial crisis and with 4.9% unemployment and guess what progressives are calling for? More stimulus, what else.  If that doesn't prove perma-stimulus is the true progressive desire then nothing will.  It will always be "obvious" to those who benefit most from expanding government that we need more government spending on something.  Meanwhile our highest in the developed world corporate tax rate continues to erode private capital investment   and the wealth creating productivity that comes from that investment.  You can count on government to funnel infrastructure dollars not to where they will do the most good but to where 1) they work to someone's best political advantage and where 2) there is already the greatest failure of progressive policy.  In this latter case the infrastructure spending will actually be counterproductive since it will just prolong the suffering and delay needed structural economic reforms, wasting all of our hard earned tax dollars in the process.

"More stimulus"??

What stimulus spending has there been? Oh, sure, we had a little bit back in 2009 and 2010, but most of that came in the form of tax cuts, not actual spending. In fact, the very brief stimulus we had halted the economic collapse and the economy did begin to recover. But slowly, way too slowly! And the effects of that stimulus has long since evaporated.

By the way, did you know that currently most government spending is directed into Republican/conservative states? In Mississippi, for example, literally 47% of the state's annual budget is in fact paid for by Federal tax dollars. The not-liberal Tax Foundation has several times over the last decade detailed how progressive states actually pay far more in Federal tax dollars than they receive in any Federal spending, causing a net loss of billions. Simultaneously, conservative states receive far more in Federal spending than they ever pay in Federal tax dollars, giving them a net gain, thanks to progressives.

And I assume you didn't actually read the column, as conservatives rarely do. Quite clearly, Dr. Krugman pointed out that the Keynesian economic principle is that you implement austerity (aka pay down the debt) at the economic boom times, but you borrow and spend during the slump to boost the economy. Note too, under Clinton we were doing exactly that, quite well. Remember the paid off debt predictions in 2000? Then we got GOP tax cuts and spending...and the debts took off again!

Economists are criticized for giving different solution at different times or situations. Like a physician prescribes different medications for different diagnoses and stages of treatments. Conservative ideologues prescribe the same cures for any problem: cut taxes and regs and repeat as often as possible while blaming the government for all ills. W's tax cuts were designed to sunset at the end of the last decade just to get a foot in the door. It took all Obama's efforts and budget brinksmanship to finally end the 3 years late. So it's no wonder that whatever your side is guilty of is projected onto the other side.

The original stimulus was far too small, and primarily dedicated to tax cuts (almost all of which went into personal savings, as predicted) and federal grants to the bankrupt states (forced to cut spending and raise taxes, sending the nation into free fall). The shortfall in infrastructure from the Stimulus was a known accounting amount. You knew it, too. In fact, predictions of waste in shovel-ready investment projects were dead wrong. We know that construction is notoriously the most inefficient in our economy and bid rigging is endemic. Yet these projects were an amazing exception (perhaps because so many firms and workers were so desperate for contracts).

By the way, economists know those federal spending programs (as opposed to the tax cuts) were absolutely free! Why? Because there was zero crowding out of private construction, which was at record lows.
Hey, ain't Kansas, Wisconsin and Louisiana lookin' great these days? Fabbalous showcases for the far right's theores, huh?

@KMW: Does the right to life extend to the life of the mother? There are Roman Catholics who would have us believe that the fetus' life is the more important of the two (leaving other children motherless in cases in which a choice must be made at the moment of parturition).  Who's to say they're wrong? Your own faith-based values are, in effect, specific only to you and should not be imposed legislatively on other women who belong to the Catholic Church or to other faiths or to no faith at all.

From what are - here Mr. Bruni and the establishment in general - trying oh so desperately save us from when with increased desperation it is all-out "stop and destroy Trump" campaign in overdrive?

The fact that his reality show experience seems to totally defeat "established" politicians including the one member of a dynasty with $130 mill election campaign money the ruling class naively in its incompetence bet on him ... is the main news.

It scares those who put the above-mentioned money on Bush & Co. expecting that the masses will, yet again, buy and go along with the standard campaign "debate and examination" of (pseudo) issues.

Citizens and voters are frustrated as never before, on both the Democratic (Sanders) and Republican (Trump) sides.

Like in Europe, where the majority of citizens, witnessing that the ruling class and the system serving - above all - its interests is "unable", actually unwilling to do anything remotely effective to protect the borders and safety and even security from terrorism-linked invasion of illegals, in despair turns to "populists", our own ruling class overplayed its hand (and their arrogant bets on Bush and Clinton are proof of that) and has one emergency session after another to derail Trump.
comments.userDisplayName: Divorce is Good For American Economy

comments.commentBody:
Dear DiGfAE:
I believe there are far more Americans who are not as frustrated and angry as you. I agree with President Obama. He said The Donald wouldn't become president because there are still enough people out there with common sense. Guess he was referring to Yours Truly.

As for Senator Sanders, who suffered an overwhelming loss tonight, a precursor to the Southern swing primaries, Dems have always contained a Far Left contingent who are never satisfied with the mainstream. Many friends of mine are always grousing about one thing or another. Since we live in New York we enjoy the luxury and little consequence to our harrumphing and grumpy attitudes. Except for '72 and '84 we remain true Blue. This convenience allows my colleagues to vote for someone who stands a snowball's chance in Hades of winning, you know, the Ralph Nader types, Green Party enthusiasts, who tell me they're voting for Senator Sanders, and if he loses, then they'll switch to Jill Stein because they "don't trust" Hillary. Mind you, these are liberal, highly educated (I love the highly educated) so-called sophisticated folks who one would think would be the last spouting FOX "News" talking points.

After the debacle this year, Republicans will probably be instituting super delegates into the mix in 2020, a lesson Dems learned in '72 with McGovern. Anyone who has a smidgen of interest in politics should take heed. What one needs is great tolerance for ambiguity.

DD
Manhattan
comments.parentUserDisplayName: Divorce is Good For American Economy

comments.commentBody:
Joe Biden and his staff opted not to call one or more witnesses who stood ready to corroborate Hill's views of Thomas. I believe that Biden acted at the behest of Republicans, so as to preserve bipartisan comity. It was an enormous error by Biden, with substantial repercussions.

Sadly, the American people have been saddled with a Supreme Court Justice of dubious ethics and legal acumen. We're all paying the price for Biden's lapse. I'm an admirer of Joe Biden, but he blew it in this instance.

History and personality. Please note that Mrs. Clinton has been in the forefront of every forward, progressive movement and has earned her record. I have never heard about or of Mr. Sanders, what has been doing, what has he been sponsored, initiated or directed? Please show some respect for those who dared to lead, expose themselves to criticism and personal attacks.

Sanders is close to done, and now it is easy to see why. Anger at Wall Street just doesn't seem to resonate much among black Democratic voters. Anger at Wall Street is issue number one for Sanders. Nothing else really comes close for him. Despite Clinton's reputation for being a puppet of Wall Street, that reputation apparently didn't hurt her among blacks in South Carolina.

Wall Street is problematic. There is no doubt in my mind that a lot of the people who work there are malignant sociopaths. But the results in South Carolina show that black Democrats don't prioritize that issue above everything else as Sanders does. This spells trouble for Sanders. Black turnout in November must be high to give Democrats any chance of retaining the White House or making gains in Congress.

In South Carolina, an economy heavily dependent on the manufacturing sector has been devastated by the loss of jobs in the textiles industry. If there was one state where black Democrats were more likely to be attracted to the anti-Wall Street message of Bernie Sanders, South Carolina was it. Because obviously Wall Street is the main culprit in pushing for the de-industrialization of the United States.

In other southern states with more advanced economies and where more black Democratic voters are employed in the tertiary sector as part of the professional managerial classes (Virginia, North Carolina, Georgia) I just don't see Sanders making large inroads with them in a bid to woo them away from Clinton.

Voting on the basis of hostility to the financial services industry is still a stretch for a lot of people, including African-Americans who have seen their jobs and livelihoods taken away by the vagaries of globalization and shareholder capitalism. Sanders has largely built his campaign around that very understandable theme, but the results in South Carolina are not encouraging for him.

I did NOT write that Wall Street is of no interest to black Democratic voters. It is merely my perception that black Democrats are not as likely to prioritize reforming Wall Street above everything else as is clearly the case with Sanders.

For the record, as far as I'm concerned President Obama should have nationalized the country's biggest investment banks on January 20, 2009. It was a huge missed opportunity during a moment of acute awareness of the destructive behavior of financial institutions and their executive-level employees. That moment is gone and won't come back until after the next crash.

I'd love to know what African Americans in South Carolina believe is more important than breaking the corporation / bank - government ties...so that our government can get back to actually legislating for us again.

And extreme inequality will not be dealt with as long as millionaire / billionaires / corporations and banks can tell our government what THEY want. (Here's a hint, it won't be reducing their wealth in any way so there is more for African Americans in South Carolina!)

Hillary has demonstrated that she can win by a large margin in a red state that she won't be able to carry in a general election.  One particularly important question that isn't being asked, but perhaps should be, is why her wins over Sanders were so close in Iowa and Nevada, while being so overwhelming in a state of the former confederacy.
A long history involved in common causes?

What struck me throughout this piece are the meager resources we as a society devote to helping families and troubled children.
It seems like such a shame that a resource like the center for Foster Care Excellence is no longer there for them. The issues don't go away once the kids get adopted. Then there is the issue of health insurance - surely a basic right for every child. Why shouldn't it be comprehensive.
And then there's the fact that a parent's work is unpaid. What work is more valuable to society - caring for children, or shaving ice? This mom is precious and needs to maintain her health and strength.
Yep, they will still need that support.
Thank you for your encouragement!!

Trump is a bully, hence, a coward in disguise. His need to brag about this and that, is another sign of insecurity and "machismo" typical of an immature male in search of redemption. Poor rich kid, so close to an empty suit, so far from filling it. Too much ego, not enough substance to escape it...and  allow  reason to show up when needed. And now, two pupils imitating his bluster, in a vain attempt to share vainglory, and to find relevancy. Insofar sexual braggadocio is concerned, not to worry, 'dog that barks doesn't bite' may be applicable; a real man does not brag. Trump as president would be a huge liability. Still, if in spite of all the negatives he succeed, we may deserve him.

@Rita J:  First off, get your terminology straight.  None of us are "pro-abortion."  That would imply that we're all living in China where you can have two kids legally- and that's it.  In actuality, we're "pro-CHOICE." Which is to say that we make our own decisions about whether to carry a fetus to term and grant other women the right to do the same.  And if you can find some way to "grow" a baby within a test-tube, from conception all the way to maturation, then you can go ahead and tell some woman whose identity you're unaware of and whose health and other circumstances you're unfamiliar with that she should place more emphasis on the fetus' body than on her own.  (If you're writing all the way from Australia you might consider sending your posts to a Chinese newspaper and trying to get them to publish one.)

Actually, we need to boost tax revenue as well as spending. Marginal tax rates of above 60 % (Ive read figures of 67 and 72 % from Stigliitz and others as necessary to control income inequality) at the high end make sense.
Just as in the first Gilded Age, the great fortunes of the second Gilded Age came as the result of government investment and government-granted monopolies. In the first Gilded Age, it started with railroads and government land grants; in the second, it started with significant government investments in basic research in the '40's through the '60's and continued with patent-related monopolies from the '70's and '80's to the present. While the patent system could use adjustment, a big advantage of granting monopolies is to get startups off the ground. Of course, the monopolies lead to huge fortunes (or can lead to), so the right way to collect on government investments is through progressive taxation. Since Reagan's presidency, the GOP has worked to shift tax burdens from the wealthy to the middle class via a series of tax cuts and subsequent readjustments. We, the people need to do some profit taking and reinvestment from our investments in new technology.

Next week, Lord Douhat will reveal how Abraham Lincoln was the root cause of the Ku Klux Klan, how President Lyndon Johnson's Civil Rights and Voting Rights Acts moved the country backwards, and how the election of a female President will be another huge step backwards....for his Privileged Whites R Us, Boys R Us, Jesus R Us coalition of serial reality-deniers, incipient racists, institutional misogynists, habitual misanthropes and Noah's Ark believers.

Is there anything else about Republican outer space you'd like to share with the class, Ross ?

Wow. Your ability to research history is an abject failure. The KKK grew out of the Democrat Party. LBJ's Civil rights act was doomed by Democrats until Republicans stepped in to save it. Judeo-Christian values are the foundation upon which this country was built. Any by the way, prior to the Great Welfare State of the mid 60s, African Americans had higher marriage rates than whites and far lower incarceration rates. But keep calling names because you have zero facts.

Anyone with common sense or a modicum of sophia knew in 2008 Obama was a dud, not a leader.  Like Bush, Obama is a flaming failure.  Any informed person knows that the rich are richer and the poor are poorer, which explains the popularity of both Sanders and Trump.  The only reason Hillary will be nominated is because the nomination is rigged in her favor: super-delegates.  It can be assumed she will not be indicted.  The Socratic method may assume moral superiority but the gentrification of SF at the expense of the poor speaks otherwise.
Apparently, being Republican means never having to say you're sorry.

The Clintons policy of being tough on "criminals" (young black men) put more of them in prison than ever before in American history. Mass incarceration in America a national disgrace, with higher rates of imprisonment than anywhere else in the world. And more than half of those in prison are black or brown. I give Hillary a lot of credit for being such an incredibly adept liar that she has been able to propagate the image of lending a helping hand to African Americans. She was actually complicit with her husband in devastating the black community through supporting the war on drugs  and accepting campaign contributions from private prison corporations. Of course now when it started to look bad for her campaign she changes her tune.
Sanders signed that bill in 1994. Hillary Clinton did not.  The crime bill was overwhelmingly supported by black leaders.  Your last name suits you.

That was her husband Bill Clinton, who was elected 25 years ago when crime rates were much higher. Are you still in the dark ages when a woman existed only as an extension of her husband?

He isn't running this year. On the ballot is a Senator and Secretary of State named HILLARY Clinton. Here is here a factual article from the non-partisan statistical organization, 538.com about her 2001-2009 Senate voting record.

http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/hillary-clinton-was-liberal-hillary-c...

Senator Sanders VOTED for the 1994 crime bill. The Republicans wanted a much worse bill. Many, many leaders in the AA community begged for the bill.

It is sad, to me, that not enough people, excepting John Lewis, for example, considered how LEO and prosecutors might apply the law - picking on people of color and going after the little guy on the street rather than the big dealers.
And, yet, in an era of gang violence and the crack epidemic destroying poor communities, the bill as flawed as it was did do some good.

Some of the whites, here, might try reading the work of black folks on that bill and its context.

The fraud who will not take a picture with a member of our own military or police. What a treat.... 5 Billion still missing from the state department, absolutely nothing accomplished as Secretary of state, and living off the government boob since 1975 ! What a jewel America, what a Jewel............If elected your grand children will enjoy an equal opportunity not to surpass the poverty level.... Suck it up America here's your queen.

Gosh, this is exactly the same comment "Edward Cousin" made a few comments before yours.

Any relation?
Right. Because Donald Trump or Marco Rubio would be so much better.
I'm guessing Eddie from Selma is closer to the real identity.

"Meaning no disrespect" at least 3 possibilities spring to mind:
1. They know she has been working on their behalf for decades and earned their trust by that effort in the trenches and the gains won for them.
2. They think she is more likely to be elected.
3. Their hard experience has taught them to be realistic and not to be persuaded by proposals that sound great but have no realistic chance of becoming reality - universal single payer health care with no premiums,copays or deductibles and only modest taxes on the middle class. Perhaps they don't feel they can afford to pursue ideal options if the cost of doing so might be to lose the modest gains they have made.
Experience....
Clinton vs Trump. The field is set. Sanders voters getting on board? Won't matter. Republican interests will ensure a Clinton victory. Will the Republican party re-constitute itself by 2024?

@epistemology,
So your saying that Clinton's already won the election and has no need for Sanders voters? Fine, there are quite a few people out there who'll be more than happy to test your theory. It would be interesting to see if Clinton would agree with you.

2-28-16@12:41 am

"Republican interests will ensure a Clinton victory."

Then why is the Republican attack machine firing all guns full blast at Hillary Clinton and none at Bernie Sanders?

Because they want a Clinton victory? In what alternate universe does that make ANY sense at all?
